bibliography.source_title: Aerosol pH and chemical regimes of sulfate formation in aerosol water during winter haze in the North China Plain
bibliography.source_authors: Tao, W., Su, H., Zheng, G., Wang, J., Wei, C., Liu, L., Ma, N., Li, M., Zhang, Q., Pöschl, U., and Cheng, Y.
bibliography.key_findings: Aerosol pH exhibits strong vertical gradient (pH ~5.4 at surface to ~0 at 3km). Different sulfate formation pathways dominate at different pH ranges: NO2/O3 at pH>4.5, TMI/H2O2 at pH<4.5. Rapid sulfate production maintained over pH 4.2-5.7 with pathway transitions.

bibliography.source_title: Sulfate formation is dominated by manganese-catalyzed oxidation of SO2 on aerosol surfaces during haze events
bibliography.source_authors: Wang, W., Liu, M., Wang, T., Song, Y., Zhou, L., Cao, J., Hu, J., Tang, G., Chen, Z., Li, Z., Xu, Z., Peng, C., Lian, C., Chen, Y., Pan, Y., Zhang, Y., Sun, Y., Li, W., Zhu, T., Tian, H., Ge, M.
bibliography.key_findings: Mn-catalyzed SO2 oxidation on aerosol surfaces contributes 69.2% ± 5.0% of particulate sulfur production during haze. Rate is 1-2 orders of magnitude larger than previously known routes. Sulfate formation rate: 14.1-24.5 μg m-3 h-1.

bibliography.source_title: Aerosol high water contents favor sulfate and secondary organic aerosol formation from fossil fuel combustion emissions
bibliography.source_authors: Huang, X., Liu, Z., Ge, Y., Li, Q., Wang, X., Fu, H., Zhu, J., Zhou, B., Wang, L., George, C., Wang, Y., Wang, X., Su, J., Xue, L., Yu, S., Mellouki, A., Chen, J.
bibliography.key_findings: High aerosol water content promotes EC particle aging and SOA formation. Under RH>85%, multiphase SO2 oxidation by in-particle nitrite/HONO leads to substantial sulfate increase. PM2.5 mass 2.0-4.3x higher during high RH episodes.

bibliography.source_title: Mineral dust and NOx promote the conversion of SO2 to sulfate in heavy pollution days
bibliography.source_authors: He, H., Wang, Y., Ma, Q., Ma, J., Chu, B., Ji, D., Tang, G., Liu, C., Zhang, H., Hao, J.
bibliography.key_findings: NO2 and SO2 have synergistic effects on mineral dust surfaces. Coexistence of NO2 significantly promotes sulfite to sulfate oxidation. O2 is the key oxidant in the process. Sulfate formation is main reason for fine particle growth.

bibliography.source_title: Importance of gas-particle partitioning of ammonia in haze formation in the rural agricultural environment
bibliography.source_authors: Xu, J., Chen, J., Zhao, N., Wang, G., Yu, G., Li, H., Huo, J., Lin, Y., Fu, Q., Guo, H., Deng, C., Lee, S.-H., Chen, J., Huang, K.
bibliography.key_findings: Gas-particle partitioning of ammonia ε(NH4+), not ammonia concentration, plays critical role in SNA formation. AWC plays predominant role in regulating ε(NH4+). Self-amplifying feedback mechanism: higher AWC → higher ε(NH4+) → more SNA → more AWC.

bibliography.source_title: Aqueous production of secondary organic aerosol from fossil-fuel emissions in winter Beijing haze
bibliography.key_findings: Fast aqueous-phase oxidation of POA at high RH forms SOA. Ring-breaking oxidation of PAHs leads to functionalization as carbonyls and carboxylic acids. Aq-SOA accounts for ~20% of total OA in haze events.

relationships.description: Aerosol pH controls dominant sulfate formation pathway: NO2/O3 at pH>4.5, TMI/H2O2 at pH<4.5
relationships.mechanism: Aerosol pH controls the dominant sulfate formation pathway. At pH > 4.5, S(IV) oxidation by NO2 and O3 dominates, while at pH < 4.5, oxidation by H2O2 and transition metal ions (TMI) becomes dominant. Lower pH enhances SO2 uptake and aqueous-phase oxidation kinetics through increased Henry's law solubility.

conditions.original_text: pH range: 4.2-5.7 for rapid sulfate production

normalized.interpretation: Optimal pH range for rapid sulfate production with pathway transitions
Minimum RH required for aerosol liquid water to be present
Sufficient SO2 precursor for sulfate formation

relationships.quantitative_effect: Rapid sulfate production maintained over pH 4.2-5.7 with pathway transitions
relationships.notes: pH exhibits strong vertical gradient: ~5.4 at surface to ~0 at 3km altitude

relationships.description: Mn-catalyzed SO2 oxidation on aerosol surfaces is dominant sulfate formation pathway during haze
relationships.mechanism: Manganese-catalyzed oxidation of SO2 on aerosol surfaces is the dominant sulfate formation pathway during haze. Mn(III) acts as intermediate that oxidizes S(IV). The reaction involves: SO2 + O2 + Mn(OH)x → SO5·- + Mn2+, followed by HSO5- formation and sulfate production with NH3. This heterogeneous surface reaction is 1-2 orders of magnitude faster than aqueous-phase routes.

normalized.interpretation: Optimal RH range for Mn-catalyzed surface oxidation
Experimental temperature condition, approximately 25°C
Requires manganese ions in aerosol phase
Requires ammonia for neutralization step

relationships.source_title: Sulfate formation is dominated by manganese-catalyzed oxidation of SO2 on aerosol surfaces during haze events
relationships.source_authors: Wang, W., Liu, M., Wang, T., et al.
relationships.source_quote: the contribution of the manganese-catalyzed oxidation of SO2 on aerosol surfaces is approximately one to two orders of magnitude larger than previously known routes, and contributes 69.2% ± 5.0% of the particulate sulfur production during haze events
relationships.quantitative_effect: Sulfate formation rate: 14.1-24.5 μg m-3 h-1; contributes 69.2% ± 5.0% of particulate sulfur
relationships.notes: Reaction inhibited by more acidic conditions; pH is critical factor

relationships.description: High ALWC provides reaction medium for enhanced aqueous-phase chemistry and SIA formation
relationships.mechanism: High aerosol liquid water content (ALWC) provides reaction medium for enhanced aqueous-phase chemistry. ALWC promotes aging of EC-containing particles and facilitates SOA formation. Under high RH (>85%), multiphase oxidation of SO2 by in-particle nitrite/HONO and HMS formation leads to substantial sulfate increase. ALWC enhances gas uptake by increasing effective Henry's law constants.

normalized.interpretation: Threshold RH for significant aqueous-phase chemistry enhancement
Requires particles capable of water uptake (sulfate, nitrate, ammonium)
Requires NO2 or HONO as oxidants

relationships.source_authors: Huang, X., Liu, Z., Ge, Y., et al.
relationships.source_quote: the synergistic effect of elevated aerosol water content and particles originating from fossil fuel combustion significantly enhanced the rapid formation of sulfate and SOAs under high humidity conditions
relationships.quantitative_effect: PM2.5 mass 2.0-4.3x higher during high RH episodes compared to clean period
relationships.notes: Aged EC-containing particles: 59% during RH 88% vs 16% during clean period

relationships.description: Mineral dust provides catalytic surfaces for SO2 oxidation with NO2 synergy
relationships.mechanism: Mineral dust provides catalytic surfaces for SO2 oxidation. NO2 and SO2 have synergistic effects when reacting on mineral dust surfaces (Al2O3, CaO, ZnO, TiO2, Fe2O3, MgO). Coexistence of NO2 significantly promotes oxidation of surface sulfite to sulfate, with O2 as the key oxidant. This reduces atmospheric environmental capacity for SO2.

normalized.interpretation: Requires mineral dust particles in atmosphere
Synergistic effect requires both NO2 and SO2 present
O2 is always available in atmosphere - implicit condition

relationships.source_quote: coexistence with NOx can reduce the environmental capacity for SO2, leading to rapid conversion of SO2 to sulfate because NO2 and SO2 have a synergistic effect when they react on the surface of mineral dust
relationships.quantitative_effect: PM2.5 peak concentrations over 300 μg/m³ during dust-influenced haze episodes
relationships.notes: Combined motor vehicle exhaust and coal-fired emissions reduce atmospheric capacity for SO2

relationships.description: AWC regulates NH4+ partitioning creating self-amplifying feedback for SNA formation
relationships.mechanism: Aerosol water content (AWC) regulates gas-particle partitioning of ammonia (ε(NH4+)), which plays a critical role in secondary inorganic aerosol (SNA) formation. Higher AWC leads to higher ε(NH4+), which increases SNA, which in turn increases AWC - creating a self-amplifying feedback mechanism. This explains why ammonia emission reduction alone may not effectively reduce SNA.

normalized.interpretation: High ammonia concentration environment

conditions.original_text: RH sufficient for aerosol water formation

normalized.interpretation: Requires sufficient RH for AWC, but no specific threshold given in source
Temperature influences NH4NO3 equilibrium but AWC is dominant factor

relationships.notes: Reduction in ammonia emissions alone may not reduce SNA effectively

relationships.description: Fast aqueous-phase oxidation of POA at high RH forms SOA via PAH ring-breaking
relationships.mechanism: Fast aqueous-phase oxidation of directly emitted primary organic aerosol (POA) occurs at high relative humidity. Ring-breaking oxidation of POA aromatic species (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons - PAHs) leads to functionalization as carbonyls and carboxylic acids, forming secondary organic aerosol (aq-SOA). This pathway is significant for fossil-fuel derived SOA.

normalized.interpretation: High RH condition, 81% ± 10% means approximately ≥71%
Winter temperature condition, approximately 1°C

conditions.original_text: POA from fossil fuel combustion present

normalized.interpretation: Requires primary organic aerosol from fossil fuel sources

relationships.description: At pH > 5.5 with high LWC, NO2/HONO oxidation pathway dominates sulfate formation
relationships.mechanism: At aerosol pH > 5.5 with high liquid water content, aqueous oxidation of SO2 by dissolved NO2 and nitrous acid (HONO) is favored. This pathway becomes dominant in megacity regions like Beijing. The NO2 pathway prevails in areas with high NOx emissions and moderately acidic to neutral aerosol conditions.

normalized.interpretation: High pH condition favoring NO2 oxidation pathway
Requires high liquid water content, no specific threshold given
Requires NO2 as oxidant

relationships.description: At pH 4-5 with low LWC, TMI-catalyzed oxidation dominates sulfate formation
relationships.mechanism: At aerosol pH 4-5 with low liquid water content, manganese-catalyzed oxidation on particle surfaces predominates in sulfate formation. The TMI pathway dominates in inland and coastal regions. Doubling TMI species sources almost triples sulfate production, indicating high sensitivity to TMI availability.

normalized.interpretation: Moderately acidic pH range favoring TMI pathway
Requires low liquid water content, no specific threshold given
Requires transition metal ions (Fe, Mn) as catalysts

relationships.description: RH directly controls ALWC through hygroscopic growth, creating positive feedback for SIA
relationships.mechanism: Relative humidity directly controls aerosol liquid water content through hygroscopic growth of particles. At RH > 85%, particles take up significant water, providing medium for aqueous-phase chemistry. Hygroscopic particles (containing sulfate, nitrate, ammonium) show enhanced water uptake, creating positive feedback for secondary aerosol formation.

normalized.interpretation: Minimum RH for initial hygroscopic water uptake
Threshold for significant ALWC enhancement
normalized.note: This is the more stringent condition for significant effect

normalized.interpretation: Requires hygroscopic particles (sulfate, nitrate, ammonium)

relationships.description: Low temperature shifts NH4NO3 equilibrium toward particle phase, increasing PM2.5
relationships.mechanism: Temperature decrease shifts NH4NO3 equilibrium toward particle phase. Lower temperatures favor condensation of semi-volatile species and reduce evaporation of particulate ammonium nitrate. This temperature-dependent partitioning significantly affects PM2.5 mass, especially in winter when temperatures are low.

normalized.interpretation: Temperature below 25°C (298K) favors particle-phase partitioning
Requires ammonia and nitric acid precursors
RH also affects partitioning but temperature is primary driver

relationships.notes: Winter conditions (274-277 K) favor particle-phase partitioning

relationships.description: ALWC enables HMS formation from S(IV) + HCHO reaction, contributing to unexplained sulfate
relationships.mechanism: Aerosol liquid water enables aqueous-phase formation of hydroxymethanesulfonate (HMS) from reaction of S(IV) with formaldehyde (HCHO). HMS formation is significant under high RH conditions and contributes to unexplained sulfate in models. This pathway is particularly important during fog/cloud processing.

normalized.interpretation: High RH required for significant HMS formation
Requires formaldehyde as reactant
Requires dissolved S(IV) species (SO2·H2O, HSO3-, SO3²-)

relationships.description: Fe-rich particles catalyze SO2 oxidation through Fe(III) catalysis in aqueous phase
relationships.mechanism: Iron-rich particles, particularly those containing oxalate, facilitate SO2 oxidation through catalytic processes. Fe(III) can catalyze S(IV) oxidation in aqueous phase. Iron solubility and speciation (Fe3+-Fe2+ cycling) depend on dust mineralogy, particle acidity, and heterogeneous redox reactions.

normalized.interpretation: Requires iron-rich particles, especially those with oxalate
Acidic conditions enhance Fe solubility, but no specific pH given
Requires aerosol liquid water for aqueous-phase catalysis
